DOC.HEAD: Israel Broadcasts First Pictures of South Lebanon Prison
DOC.TEXT: Israel television broadcast unique footage Friday of a former French hostage in Lebanon interviewing Moslem Shiite prisoners of an Israeli-backed militia. The taping by Roger Auque, who was released in November 1987 after 10 months of captivity in Beirut, marks the first time outsiders have been allowed in the South Lebanon Army's el-Khiam prison. The Israeli-backed militia had never allowed Red Cross or U.N. officials to enter the prison, which is just north of the Lebanese town of Marjayoun. Prisoners interviewed by Auque said they were treated adequately, but they expressed hope that Lebanese Shiite militias would agree to a prisoner exchange with Israel. The television said the Defense Ministry agreed to allow Auque to tape in the stark prison to show conditions are acceptable and to increase pressure on the Lebanon's Shiite Amal and Hezbollah militias to agree to a prisoner exchange with Israel. Israel television said the broadcast was made for a French television network but gave no other details. The television said an estimated 300 prisoners, mainly Shiites, are held in el-Khiam. The prisoners include both guerrillas and criminal suspects. Israel has offered to swap the prisoners and Sheik Abdul-Karim Obeid, a pro-Iranian Shiite cleric abducted by Israel in August, for three Israeli servicemen and all other foreign hostages held in Lebanon.
